Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a devotee in 'grotesque' style, or of a youthful satyr. Mould-made from a two-piece mould and solid, with neck plug where it would have joined a hollow figurine. Red-brown Nile silt fabric, with abundant mica and sand inclusions. Head only.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. Parallels from Naukratis (Cambridge NA697, NA701; Boston MFA 86.453) and an unprovenanced piece, dated to the 1st century BC (Dresden, Fischer 1994, Pl. 45, no.456). Fischer, J. 1994. ‘Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen’. Tübingen: Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.590) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5849 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
